_prev_prog_3.Description: Regulated under OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Name: Gilcrest Gas Plant

Gilcrest, CO 80651

Parent Company: Aka Energy Group, LLC

RMP Facility ID: 100000156118



AKA ENERGY GROUP, LLC

GILCREST GAS PLANT

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



Executive Summary



Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:



The Gilcrest Gas Plant has implemented all the elements of a Program 3 Risk Management Plan(RMP) and all the elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program.



The Gilcrest Gas Plant Emergency Action Plan is site-specific. It includes required actions by plant employees as well as required notification and coordination with local responders and agencies. All employees are trained in the execution of the Emergency Action Plan.

 

The Stationary Source and Regulated substances:



The Gilcrest Gas Plant processes raw natural gas into commercial natural gas and Y-Grade natural gas liquids. The raw natural gas enters the plant by pipeline. The finished products are delivered to pipelines or onto trucks for local sales. The regulated substances are natural gas, condensate and Y-Grade natural gas liquids.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program:



The Gilcrest Gas Plant has implemented all the elements of a Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP) and all the elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program. Key elements of these programs include:



Process Safety Information: A variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process including Safety Data Sheets (SDSs), process and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs), process flow diagrams (PFDs), plot plans, and operation and maintenance manuals for specific equipment.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): A systematic examination of the plant to identify possible hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. PHA update and revalidation is conducted at least every five years per OSHA PSM compliance requirements. 



Operating Procedures: The Gilcrest Gas

Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) initial start-up, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) emergency operations, (6) normal shutdown, and (7) startup after turnaround. Operating procedures are reviewed and revalidated on an annual basis.



Training: The plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. The program includes classroom, on the job training (OJT), and written testing. Employees are tested to demonstrate competency.



Mechanical Integrity: The Gilcrest Gas Plant has well established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in safe operating condition.



Management of Change: Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. MOCs are managed electronically through the use of a structured software program.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR's): The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing modified equipment into service.



Compliance Audits: Audits are conducted on 3-year basis to ensure that the facility is in compliance with applicable RMP / PSM procedures and regulations.



Incident Investigation: The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts concerning an incident or near miss and to develop corrective actions to prevent recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.



Employee Participation: Employees are consulted on the development of the required elements of the PSM/RMP Program. Employees participate by developing, revising, and auditing the PSM/RMP program where applicable.



Contractors: Gilcrest Gas Plant uses contractors to suppl

ement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors, (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) are aware of any hazards in the workplace, (3) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (4) understand and follow site safety rules, and (5) inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.



Safe Work Practices and Procedures: 



Aka has established policies and procedures to ensure that safe work practices and procedures are adhered to at the facility. Policies and procedures include controlled facility access, contractor orientation, training and testing, lockout/ tagout, hot work, and confined space entry. 



In addition, the plant utilizes a computerized process control system that will safely shut down the operation if the process exceeds safe operating conditions. The computerized process control system has its own power backup.



Five-year Accident History:



No major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion, involving one or more regulated substances that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment has occurred in the last 5 years.



Emergency Response Program Information:



The Gilcrest Gas Plant maintains an Integrated Contingency Plan / Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to protect employees, contractors, public and the environment from hazards associated with accidental releases of regulated substances. The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of regulated substances, including the possibility of associated fires or explosions. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, if a release occurs. Employees receive training in these procedures annuall

y to perform emergency response duties. The program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the gas plant processes. Emergency response program changes are administered through the Management of Change (MOC) process.



The overall emergency response program for Gilcrest Gas Plant is coordinated with Gilcrest / Platteville Fire Protection District. This coordination includes attending periodic meetings, which includes local emergency response officials and industry representatives. The Gilcrest Gas Plant has 24-hour communications capability with the Gilcrest / Platteville Fire Protection District.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Aka is a member of various industry trade organizations that continuously review changes in technology that lead to improved safety practices.
